channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [WICKET-6707] Property setter parameter type is assumed to be equal to getter return type
item.description:
I am getting error: Method [public boolean cz.kb.dcs.module_transaction.api.data_objects.cexi.TransactionFormItem.isInstantPayment()]. Can't convert null value to a primitive class: boolean

This is due to

if (setMethod != null) {
    // getMethod is always there and if the value will be set through a setMethod then
    // the getMethod return type will be its type. Else we have to look at the
    // parameters if the setter but getting the return type is quicker
    type = getMethod.getReturnType();
}

I have this getter and setter:

public boolean isInstantPayment() {
    return instantPayment == null ? false : instantPayment.booleanValue();
}

public void setInstantPayment(final Boolean instantPayment) {
    this.instantPayment = instantPayment;
}

So setting NULL would be possible (the property itself is object Boolean). Although it is not according to Java Beans specification.
item.summary: Property setter parameter type is assumed to be equal to getter return type

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Please provide a stacktrace!
Also please provide a quickstart / test case.

Stacktrace:

WICKET-6707 Property setter parameter type is assumed to be equal to getter return type

Add a test for WICKET-6707.
davesman Please see the test case that I've added and modify it so that it starts failing. Thank you!

mgrigorov Hello,

just try to set null:

PropertyResolver.setValue("instantPayment", bean, null, CONVERTER);

The Object Boolean should accept null value (the property is also object Boolean). And the getter is written to deal with null values.

Because when checkbox is missing (hidden) on the page, the PropertyResolverConverter#convert return null when input is null:

	public <T> T convert(Object object, Class<T> clz)
	{
		if (object == null)
		{
			return null;
		}

Commit 80e9119eb04b8c670c24a97c89c28ddcebc1374b in wicket's branch refs/heads/master from Martin Tzvetanov Grigorov
[ https://gitbox.apache.org/repos/asf?p=wicket.git;h=80e9119 ]

WICKET-6707 Property setter parameter type is assumed to be equal to getter return type

Use the setter instead of the getter when checking in PropertyResolver#setValue()

[ https://gitbox.apache.org/repos/asf?p=wicket.git;h=0d22476 ]

WICKET-6707 Property setter parameter type is assumed to be equal to getter return type

Use the setter instead of the getter when checking in PropertyResolver#setValue()

(cherry picked from commit 80e9119eb04b8c670c24a97c89c28ddcebc1374b)
(cherry picked from commit a3c19f7daaf0cf6bf121bf8667987b7b3e672ce2)

mgrigorov I think it should have been changed here:

if (setMethod != null)
{
	// getMethod is always there and if the value will be set through a setMethod then
	// the getMethod return type will be its type. Else we have to look at the
	// parameters if the setter but getting the return type is quicker
	type = getMethod.getReturnType();
}

Because the type variable is also used during the convert call

if (type != null)
{
    converted = converter.convert(value, type);

And the convert method should also be called with the correct type of the setter parameter.

Commit 15821cf5b62b3fc40611ce5e6717aaaa746505d1 in wicket's branch refs/heads/wicket-8.x from Martin Tzvetanov Grigorov
[ https://gitbox.apache.org/repos/asf?p=wicket.git;h=15821cf ]

WICKET-6707 Use only setMethod in PropertyResolver#setValue()

Commit 9f29f68e560c14d3171151ddea10667d2930d333 in wicket's branch refs/heads/master from Martin Tzvetanov Grigorov
[ https://gitbox.apache.org/repos/asf?p=wicket.git;h=9f29f68 ]

Thank you for reviewing the change, davesman!
I've also improved the exception messages!

OK  !

And now mgrigorov you can use the type variable also here during the primitive check:

if (setMethod != null && setMethod.getParameterTypes()[0].isPrimitive())

It would look nicer this way:

if (setMethod != null && type.isPrimitive())
